Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in biology

Sub_topics.description: Design experiments to solve problems set in a practical context, including selecting suitable apparatus, equipment and techniques; apply scientific knowledge from across the specification to the practical scenario (HSW3).
Identify variables that must be controlled (where appropriate) in a biological investigation, and justify why controlling them is necessary to obtain valid results.
Evaluate whether an experimental method is appropriate to meet expected outcomes; judge if the procedure will answer the question/hypothesis and generate suitable data (HSW6).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in biology

Sub_topics.description: Use a wide range of practical apparatus and techniques correctly, as required by specification content and Practical Endorsement skills; demonstrate safe, competent operation in context (HSW4).
Select and use appropriate units for biological measurements and calculations, including conversions where needed (M0.1).
Present observations and data in an appropriate scientific format (e.g. tables, annotated observations), with clarity and conventions suitable for biology (HSW8).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in biology

Sub_topics.description: Process, analyse and interpret qualitative and quantitative experimental results, including reaching valid conclusions where appropriate (HSW5).
Use appropriate mathematical skills to analyse quantitative biological data; select relevant calculations and methods as in the mathematical requirements (HSW3).
Use significant figures appropriately in recording and reporting measurements and calculated values (M1.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plot and interpret graphs (axes, gradients, intercepts)
Sub_topics.description: Plot and interpret suitable graphs from experimental results, including: selecting and labelling axes with appropriate scales, quantities and units; measuring gradients and intercepts; interpret relationships shown (M3.2, M3.3, M3.4, M3.5).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in biology

Sub_topics.description: Evaluate results and draw justified conclusions, considering whether evidence supports the conclusion and whether alternative explanations exist (HSW6).
Identify anomalies in experimental measurements (outliers or inconsistent readings) and consider plausible causes (biological variation, method error, equipment issues).
Recognise and explain limitations in experimental procedures (e.g. uncontrolled variables, low resolution of apparatus, sampling bias, confounding factors).
Assess precision and accuracy of measurements and data, including margins of error, percentage errors and uncertainties in apparatus; calculate % error where required (M1.11).
Refine experimental design by suggesting specific improvements to procedures and apparatus; justify how improvements increase validity, reliability, accuracy or precision (HSW3).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in biology

Sub_topics.description: Apply investigative approaches and methods to practical work, including solving problems in a practical context; demonstrate independence in planning and adapting methods (HSW3).
Safely and correctly use a range of practical equipment and materials; identify potential hazards and explain how to minimise risks (HSW4).
Follow written practical instructions accurately to carry out techniques and procedures as intended.
Make and record observations and measurements accurately and methodically using appropriate units and conventions (HSW8).
Keep appropriate records of experimental activities, including methods, raw data, processed data, and conclusions as required for the Practical Endorsement.
Present information and data in a scientific way (e.g. tables, graphs, annotated diagrams, structured write-ups) suitable for communicating findings (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Use software/tools to process data and report
Sub_topics.description: Use appropriate software and tools to process data, carry out research and report findings; translate between numerical and graphical outputs where relevant (M3.1, HSW3).
Use online and offline research skills, including evaluating and using information from websites, textbooks and other printed scientific sources.
Correctly cite sources of information used in practical planning and reporting, using appropriate scientific referencing approaches.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Use a wide range of instruments and techniques
Sub_topics.description: Use a wide range of experimental and practical instruments, equipment and techniques appropriate to the specification’s knowledge and understanding (HSW4).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in biology

Sub_topics.description: Use appropriate apparatus to record quantitative measurements including mass, time, volume, temperature, length and pH (HSW4).
Use appropriate instrumentation to record quantitative measurements, such as a colorimeter or potometer (HSW4).
Use laboratory glassware for experimental techniques including serial dilutions; plan dilution series and maintain accuracy (HSW4).
Use a light microscope at low and high power, including using a graticule for measurement and scaling (HSW4).
Produce scientific drawings from observations with appropriate detail, labels and annotations, using correct biological drawing conventions (HSW8).
Use qualitative reagents to identify biological molecules (e.g. proteins, sugars, starch, lipids) safely and correctly (HSW4).
Separate biological compounds using thin layer chromatography (TLC) or paper chromatography, and/or electrophoresis; interpret separation patterns and relate to identity/purity (HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ethical use of organisms (responses and physiology)
Sub_topics.description: Use organisms safely and ethically to measure (i) plant or animal responses and (ii) physiological functions; apply ethical considerations and minimise harm (HSW4, HSW10).
Use microbiological aseptic techniques safely, including using agar plates and broth; prevent contamination and manage biohazards (HSW4).
Use instruments safely for dissection of an animal or plant organ; expose and identify structures and record observations appropriately (HSW4).
Use sampling techniques in fieldwork (e.g. quadrats, transects, sweep nets, pitfall traps) appropriately to collect ecological data (HSW4).
Use ICT such as computer modelling, data loggers to collect data, and software to process data; ensure appropriate selection of tools and correct handling of digital data (HSW3, HSW4).

Use microscopy to observe and investigate different types of cell and cell structure in a range of eukaryotic organisms; understand images from light microscope, transmission electron microscope (TEM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) (HSW1, HSW7).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prepare microscope slides; graticule and micrometer
Sub_topics.description: Prepare and examine microscope slides for light microscopy, including calibration and use of an eyepiece graticule and stage micrometer (PAG1, HSW4).
Use staining in light microscopy, including differential staining to identify different cellular components and cell types; interpret outcomes (PAG1, HSW4, HSW5).
Represent cell structure as seen under the light microscope using drawings and annotated diagrams of whole cells or cells in tissue sections; follow biological drawing conventions (PAG1).

Use and manipulate the magnification formula: magnification = size of image / size of real object; rearrange to find unknowns; apply with correct units and significant figures (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.8, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).

Explain the difference between magnification and resolution; compare achievable resolution and magnification for light microscopes, TEM and SEM; no requirement to recall exact numerical values (M0.2, M0.3, HSW7, HSW8).

Describe ultrastructure of eukaryotic cells and outline functions of: nucleus, nucleolus, nuclear envelope, rough and smooth endoplasmic reticulum (ER), Golgi apparatus, ribosomes, mitochondria, lysosomes, chloroplasts, plasma membrane, centrioles, cell wall, flagella and cilia (M0.2).
Interpret photomicrographs of cellular components in a range of eukaryotic cells, including TEM and SEM images; identify structures and infer function.
Explain the interrelationship between organelles involved in production and secretion of proteins (e.g. nucleus → ribosomes/RER → Golgi → vesicles → exocytosis).
Explain the importance of the cytoskeleton in providing mechanical strength, aiding transport within cells, and enabling cell movement (HSW2).
Compare similarities and differences in structure and ultrastructure of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells; apply microscopy evidence where relevant (PAG1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydrogen bonding and properties of water
Sub_topics.description: Explain how hydrogen bonding occurs between water molecules and relate this (and other properties of water) to roles in living organisms: solvent, transport medium, coolant, and habitat; use examples from prokaryotes and eukaryotes; apply to novel contexts (HSW2, HSW8).
Explain monomers and polymers; describe importance of condensation and hydrolysis reactions in forming and breaking biological molecules; relate to macromolecule structure/function.
Recall chemical elements making up key biological molecules: carbohydrates (C,H,O), lipids (C,H,O), proteins (C,H,O,N,S), nucleic acids (C,H,O,N,P).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Glucose and ribose structures (α/β glucose; hexose/pentose)
Sub_topics.description: Describe ring structure and properties of glucose (hexose monosaccharide) and structure of ribose (pentose monosaccharide); distinguish α-glucose vs β-glucose; distinguish hexose vs pentose.
Explain synthesis and breakdown of disaccharides and polysaccharides via formation/breakage of glycosidic bonds; include sucrose, lactose and maltose as named disaccharides.
Describe structures of starch (amylose and amylopectin), glycogen and cellulose; include key structural features relevant to function (HSW8).
Explain how structures and properties of glucose, starch, glycogen and cellulose relate to functions in living organisms (e.g. energy storage, structural support) (HSW2, HSW8).
Describe structure of a triglyceride and a phospholipid as macromolecules; include saturated vs unsaturated fatty acids and how double bonds affect shape/properties.
Explain synthesis and breakdown of triglycerides via formation and breakage of ester bonds between fatty acids and glycerol.

Explain how properties of triglycerides, phospholipids and cholesterol relate to their functions, including hydrophobic/hydrophilic regions and energy content; apply in contexts of prokaryotes and eukaryotes (HSW2, HSW8).
Describe the general structure of an amino acid (amine group, carboxyl group, R group, hydrogen on central carbon) and how variation in R group leads to different amino acids.
Explain synthesis and breakdown of dipeptides and polypeptides via formation and breakage of peptide bonds (condensation and hydrolysis).

Explain primary, secondary, tertiary and quaternary protein structure; include roles of hydrogen bonding, hydrophobic/hydrophilic interactions, disulfide bonds and ionic bonds in stabilising structure (HSW8).

Describe structure and function of globular proteins including a conjugated protein; include haemoglobin as conjugated globular protein with prosthetic group, a named enzyme, and insulin; relate structure to function (PAG10).
Explain properties and functions of fibrous proteins; include collagen, keratin and elastin (no detailed structure required) and relate to mechanical roles in organisms.

Recognise symbols and describe involvement in biological processes of: Ca2+, Na+, K+, H+, NH4+, NO3−, HCO3−, Cl−, PO4^3−, OH−; understand roles where applicable (e.g. nerve impulses, buffers, cofactors).

Carry out and interpret chemical tests: biuret for proteins; Benedict’s for reducing sugars and for non-reducing sugars (including required hydrolysis step); iodine for starch; emulsion test for lipids (PAG9, HSW3, HSW4, HSW5).

Use quantitative methods to determine concentration of a chemical substance in solution, including principles and application of colorimetry; produce/interpret calibration curves where needed (PAG5, HSW3, HSW4, HSW5).

Explain principles and uses of paper and thin layer chromatography (TLC) to separate biological molecules/compounds; carry out practical investigations to analyse biological solutions using paper/TLC; calculate Rf = distance moved by solute / distance moved by solvent; apply to separating proteins, carbohydrates, vitamins and nucleic acids (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.3, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4; PAG6; HSW2, HSW3, HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nucleotide structure; RNA vs DNA; purines/pyrimidines
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure of a nucleotide (pentose sugar, nitrogenous base, phosphate) as monomer of nucleic acids; distinguish RNA vs DNA nucleotides; identify purines vs pyrimidines; identify type of pentose sugar (ribose vs deoxyribose) (PAG10).
Explain synthesis and breakdown of polynucleotides via formation and breakage of phosphodiester bonds (condensation/hydrolysis) and implications for backbone structure.
Describe structures of ADP and ATP as phosphorylated nucleotides: ribose + adenine + inorganic phosphate groups; relate to phosphorylation and energy transfer concepts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: DNA structure (double helix, base pairing, antiparallel)
Sub_topics.description: Describe DNA structure: hydrogen bonding between complementary base pairs (A–T, G–C) on two antiparallel polynucleotide strands forming a double helix; relate bonding to stability and replication.
Carry out/understand practical purification of DNA by precipitation; explain steps and why precipitation isolates DNA (PAG9, HSW3, HSW4).

Explain semi-conservative DNA replication including roles of helicase and DNA polymerase; explain importance of accurate replication for conserving genetic information; recognise occurrence of random, spontaneous mutations; at AS level no need to distinguish mutation types (HSW8).
Explain genetic code as triplet, non-overlapping, degenerate and universal; explain how a gene determines amino acid sequence in a polypeptide (primary protein structure).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Transcription and translation (roles of RNA types)
Sub_topics.description: Explain transcription and translation leading to polypeptide synthesis; include roles of RNA polymerase, mRNA, tRNA and rRNA; relate codons/anticodons and ribosome function (HSW8).
Explain role of enzymes in catalysing reactions affecting metabolism at cellular and whole organism level; link enzyme action to biological structure and function.
Distinguish enzymes catalysing intracellular vs extracellular reactions; include catalase (intracellular) and amylase (extracellular) as examples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mechanism of enzyme action (lock-and-key; induced fit)
Sub_topics.description: Explain mechanism of enzyme action including tertiary structure, specificity, active site, lock-and-key hypothesis, induced-fit hypothesis, enzyme–substrate complex, enzyme–product complex, product formation, and lowering of activation energy (HSW1, HSW8).

Explain effects of pH, temperature, enzyme concentration and substrate concentration on enzyme activity; include temperature coefficient Q10 where Q10 = R2 / R1 (rate at higher temperature / rate at lower temperature).

Plan/carry out/interpret practical investigations into effects of pH, temperature, enzyme concentration and substrate concentration on enzyme activity; include opportunities for serial dilutions, controlling variables, calculating rates and errors, graphing and tangents (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.3, M1.11, M3.1, M3.2, M3.3, M3.5, M3.6; PAG4; HSW1, HSW2, HSW4, HSW5, HSW6, HSW8).
Explain need for coenzymes and cofactors in some enzyme-controlled reactions; include chloride ion as cofactor for amylase and vitamins as sources of coenzymes (PAG4).

Explain effects of inhibitors on rate of enzyme-controlled reactions; include competitive vs non-competitive; reversible vs non-reversible; and end-product inhibition; interpret inhibitor data/graphs (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.3, M1.11, M3.1, M3.2, M3.3, M3.5, M3.6; PAG4; HSW1, HSW2, HSW4, HSW5, HSW6, HSW8).

Explain roles of membranes within and at surface of cells: partially permeable barriers between cell and environment, between organelles and cytoplasm and within organelles; sites of chemical reactions; sites of cell communication (cell signalling).

Describe fluid mosaic model; explain roles of phospholipids, cholesterol, glycolipids, proteins and glycoproteins; include membrane-bound receptors as sites where hormones and drugs bind (M0.2, HSW1).
Explain factors affecting membrane structure and permeability, including effects of temperature and solvents; relate to phospholipid bilayer/proteins and leakage of cell contents.

Plan/carry out/interpret practical investigations into factors affecting membrane structure and permeability (e.g. beetroot pigment leakage); include handling data, % error/uncertainty and graphing (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.6, M1.11, M3.1, M3.2, M3.3, M3.5, M3.6; PAG5, PAG8; HSW1, HSW2, HSW3, HSW4, HSW5, HSW6).

Explain movement of molecules across membranes: diffusion and facilitated diffusion as passive; active transport, endocytosis and exocytosis as ATP-requiring processes; relate to gradients and carrier proteins; apply to unfamiliar contexts (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.6, M1.11, M2.1, M3.1, M3.2, M3.3, M3.5, M3.6, M4.1).

Carry out/interpret practical investigations into factors affecting diffusion rates in model cells (e.g. agar cubes); relate SA:V, concentration gradients, temperature; analyse results with appropriate maths and graphs (PAG8; HSW1, HSW2, HSW3, HSW4, HSW5, HSW6).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Osmosis and water potential effects on cells
Sub_topics.description: Explain osmosis in terms of water potential gradient across a partially permeable membrane; describe effects of solutions of different water potential on plant and animal cells (e.g. turgid, plasmolysed, crenated); include quantitative interpretation where relevant (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.6, M1.10, M1.11, M2.1, M3.1, M3.2, M4.1).

Carry out/interpret practical investigations into effects of solutions of different water potential on plant and animal cells (e.g. potato cylinders, onion epidermis); determine water potential from mass/length changes and graphs; include uncertainties (PAG8; HSW1, HSW2, HSW3, HSW4, HSW5, HSW6).

Topics.Topic_name: Cell division, cell diversity and cellular organisation

Sub_topics.description: Describe cell cycle including processes during interphase (G1, S, G2), mitosis and cytokinesis leading to genetically identical daughter cells (HSW8).
Explain how the cell cycle is regulated using checkpoints to control progression; relate to ensuring DNA integrity and correct division.
Describe main stages of mitosis, including changes in nuclear envelope, chromosomes, chromatids, centromere, centrioles, spindle fibres and cell membrane (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify mitosis in plant tissue sections
Sub_topics.description: Interpret sections of plant tissue showing cell cycle and stages of mitosis; examine stained sections/squashes; produce labelled diagrams of observed stages (PAG1).
Explain significance of mitosis in life cycles: growth, tissue repair and asexual reproduction in plants, animals and fungi (HSW2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Significance of meiosis (haploid cells and variation)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of meiosis in life cycles: production of haploid cells and generation of genetic variation by independent assortment and crossing over (HSW2, HSW5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Main stages of meiosis and homologous chromosomes
Sub_topics.description: Describe main stages of meiosis: interphase, prophase 1, metaphase 1, anaphase 1, telophase 1, prophase 2, metaphase 2, anaphase 2, telophase 2; no requirement for sub-stages of prophase 1; use term homologous chromosomes correctly (PAG1, HSW8).

Explain how cells are specialised for particular functions; include erythrocytes, neutrophils, squamous and ciliated epithelial cells, sperm cells, palisade cells, root hair cells and guard cells (PAG1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Levels of organisation (cells to organ systems)
Sub_topics.description: Describe organisation of cells into tissues, organs and organ systems; include tissues: squamous and ciliated epithelia, cartilage, muscle, xylem and phloem.
Describe features and differentiation of stem cells as a renewing source of undifferentiated cells; relate to potency and specialised cell formation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bone marrow stem cells → blood cells
Sub_topics.description: Explain production of erythrocytes and neutrophils as distinct differentiated cells derived from a common stem cell in bone marrow; relate to lineage and gene expression changes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Meristem stem cells → xylem and phloem
Sub_topics.description: Explain production of xylem vessels and phloem sieve tubes as distinct differentiated outcomes derived from a common stem cell in meristems; relate to plant development.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stem cell uses in research and medicine
Sub_topics.description: Discuss potential uses of stem cells in research and medicine: repair of damaged tissues, treatment of neurological conditions (no need to recall specific conditions), and research into developmental biology; include ethical and societal considerations where relevant (HSW2, HSW5, HSW6, HSW7, HSW9, HSW10, HSW11, HSW12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Need for specialised exchange surfaces (SA:V, metabolic rate)
Sub_topics.description: Explain need for specialised exchange surfaces with reference to surface area to volume ratio (SA:V), metabolic activity, and differences between single-celled and multicellular organisms; use SA:V ratio = surface area / volume and interpret consequences (M0.1, M0.3, M0.4, M1.1, M2.1, M4.1; HSW1, HSW3, HSW5, HSW8).
Describe features of efficient exchange surfaces: increased surface area (e.g. root hair cells), thin layer (alveoli), good blood supply/ventilation to maintain gradient (gills/alveolus).

Describe structures and functions of components of mammalian gaseous exchange system; include distribution and functions of cartilage, ciliated epithelium, goblet cells, smooth muscle and elastic fibres in trachea, bronchi, bronchioles and alveoli (PAG1, HSW8).
Explain mechanism of ventilation in mammals including function of rib cage, internal and external intercostal muscles, and diaphragm; relate pressure/volume changes to airflow (HSW8).

Analyse relationship between vital capacity, tidal volume, breathing rate and oxygen uptake; interpret primary/secondary data from data logger/spirometer; perform calculations/graph interpretation where required (M0.1, M0.2, M0.4, M1.3; PAG10; HSW2, HSW3, HSW4, HSW5, HSW6).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gas exchange in bony fish and insects
Sub_topics.description: Explain mechanisms of ventilation and gas exchange in: bony fish (buccal cavity volume changes, operculum function, gill filaments and gill lamellae, countercurrent flow) and insects (spiracles, trachea, thoracic/abdominal movements changing body volume, exchange with tracheal fluid) (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dissect fish/insect trachea gas exchange system
Sub_topics.description: Dissect, examine and draw gaseous exchange system of a bony fish and/or insect trachea; produce accurate labelled biological drawings (PAG2, HSW4).
Examine microscope slides to show histology of exchange surfaces; identify adaptations and relate to diffusion gradients (PAG1, HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Need for transport systems in animals
Sub_topics.description: Explain need for transport systems in multicellular animals with reference to size, metabolic rate and SA:V; relate diffusion limitations to requirement for circulatory systems (M0.1, M0.3, M0.4, M1.1, M2.1, M4.1; HSW1, HSW3, HSW5, HSW8).
Compare single vs double and open vs closed circulatory systems in insects, fish and mammals; relate structure to efficiency and pressure differences.
Describe structure and functions of arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules and veins; include distribution of tissues within vessel walls and relate to pressure/flow (PAG2).
Explain formation of tissue fluid from plasma using hydrostatic pressure and oncotic pressure; explain differences in composition of blood, tissue fluid and lymph (HSW8).
Describe external and internal structure of mammalian heart; identify chambers, valves, vessels, and cardiac muscle features relevant to function.
Dissect, examine and draw external and internal structure of mammalian heart; produce labelled scientific drawings (PAG2, HSW4).

Explain cardiac cycle including role of valves and pressure changes in heart and associated vessels; use cardiac output = heart rate × stroke volume; interpret pressure/volume changes (HSW2, HSW5, HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrical coordination of heart (SAN, AVN, Purkyne)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how heart action is initiated and coordinated: roles of sino-atrial node (SAN), atrio-ventricular node (AVN), purkyne tissue, and myogenic nature of cardiac muscle; no detail of hormonal/nervous control required at AS level (HSW2, HSW5, HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: ECG traces: normal and abnormal patterns
Sub_topics.description: Use and interpret electrocardiogram (ECG) traces; recognise normal and abnormal heart activity: tachycardia, bradycardia, fibrillation and ectopic heartbeat only; perform relevant calculations/measurements (M0.1, M1.1, M1.3, M2.4; HSW2, HSW5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Haemoglobin transport of O2 and CO2
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of haemoglobin in transporting oxygen and carbon dioxide; include reversible binding of O2, carbonic anhydrase, formation of haemoglobinic acid, hydrogencarbonate ion, and chloride shift; relate to gas exchange and blood pH (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oxygen dissociation curves (fetal vs adult; Bohr effect)
Sub_topics.description: Interpret oxygen dissociation curves for fetal and adult human haemoglobin; explain significance of different affinities; explain Bohr effect (curve shift with different CO2 concentrations); translate between graphical and numerical interpretations (M3.1; HSW2, HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Need for transport systems in plants
Sub_topics.description: Explain need for transport systems in multicellular plants with reference to size, metabolic rate and SA:V; relate to diffusion limitations (M0.1, M0.3, M0.4, M1.1, M2.1, M4.1; HSW1, HSW3, HSW5, HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Vascular system structure and function (roots, stems, leaves)
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure and function of vascular system in roots, stems and leaves of herbaceous dicotyledonous plants; include xylem vessels, sieve tube elements and companion cells.
Examine and draw stained sections of plant tissue showing distribution of xylem and phloem; identify tissues and relate structure to function (PAG1, HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stem dissections to show xylem structure
Sub_topics.description: Dissect stems longitudinally and transversely; examine to demonstrate position and structure of xylem vessels; record/draw observations (PAG2, HSW4).
Explain transpiration process and environmental factors affecting transpiration rate; recognise transpiration as consequence of gaseous exchange; relate stomatal aperture and gradients to water loss.

Carry out/interpret practical investigations estimating transpiration rates, including use of a potometer; analyse data and apply relevant maths (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.6, M1.11, M3.1, M3.2, M3.3, M3.5, M3.6, M4.1; PAG5, PAG11; HSW2, HSW3, HSW4, HSW5, HSW6, HSW8).
Explain transport of water into, through and out of plants: apoplast and symplast pathways; movement mechanisms in terms of water potential, adhesion, cohesion, and transpiration stream (HSW2, HSW8).
Describe adaptations of plants to water availability; include xerophytes (cacti, marram grass) and hydrophytes (water lilies); relate to transpiration control and water uptake (HSW2).

Explain translocation as an energy-requiring process transporting assimilates (especially sucrose) in phloem between sources (e.g. leaves) and sinks (e.g. roots, meristem); include active loading at source and removal at sink; relate to pressure flow concepts (HSW2, HSW8).

Topics.Topic_name: Communicable diseases, disease prevention and the immune system

Sub_topics.description: Describe different pathogen types causing communicable diseases in plants and animals and use named examples: bacteria (tuberculosis (TB), ring rot (potatoes)); viruses (HIV/AIDS (human), influenza (animals), Tobacco Mosaic Virus (plants)); protoctista (malaria, potato/tomato late blight); fungi (black sigatoka (bananas), athlete’s foot (humans)); no requirement for binomial pathogen names.

Explain means of transmission of animal and plant communicable pathogens; include vectors, spores and living conditions (e.g. climate, social factors); no detail of symptoms required; no requirement to categorise as direct/indirect transmission; interpret data about transmission and spread where provided (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.5, M1.7, M3.1, M3.2; HSW1, HSW2, HSW3, HSW5, HSW6, HSW7, HSW8, HSW11, HSW12).
Describe plant defences: production of chemicals and plant responses limiting pathogen spread (e.g. callose deposition); relate to barriers and induced responses.

Describe primary non-specific defences: skin; blood clotting (limited to platelets releasing substances leading via cascade to fibrin network forming clot; no need for clotting factor names or full cascade); wound repair; inflammation; expulsive reflexes; mucous membranes; no requirement for detailed skin structure (HSW2, HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Phagocytes: structure and mode of action
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure and mode of action of phagocytes; include neutrophils and antigen-presenting cells; roles of cytokines, opsonins, phagosomes and lysosomes; relate to innate immune response (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Blood smears: examine and draw immune cells
Sub_topics.description: Examine and draw cells in blood smears, including identification of neutrophils and other relevant cells; produce labelled scientific drawings (PAG1, HSW4, HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: B and T lymphocytes in specific immune response
Sub_topics.description: Explain structure, roles and modes of action of B and T lymphocytes in specific immune response; include cell signalling (interleukins), clonal selection, clonal expansion, plasma cells, T helper cells and T killer cells (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Primary vs secondary immune responses; memory cells
Sub_topics.description: Explain primary and secondary immune responses, including roles of T memory cells and B memory cells; interpret response graphs/data (M1.3; HSW2).
Describe structure and general functions of antibodies; include general protein structure of an antibody molecule and how structure supports specificity.
Outline actions of opsonins, agglutinins and anti-toxins in immune defence; relate to pathogen neutralisation and phagocytosis enhancement.
Explain differences between active and passive immunity and between natural and artificial immunity; give examples of each (e.g. infection, vaccination, maternal antibodies, antibody injections).
Explain term autoimmune disease and describe arthritis as a named example; relate to immune system attacking self antigens.

Explain principles of vaccination and role of vaccination programmes in preventing epidemics; include routine vaccinations and reasons for changes to vaccines/programmes including global issues; interpret data on vaccine coverage/efficacy and evaluate (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.5, M1.7, M3.1, M3.2; HSW1, HSW2, HSW3, HSW5, HSW6, HSW7, HSW8, HSW9, HSW11, HSW12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sources of medicines and personalised medicine
Sub_topics.description: Discuss possible sources of medicines (microorganisms and plants) and link to need to maintain biodiversity; outline potential for personalised medicines; evaluate benefits/risks (HSW7, HSW9, HSW11, HSW12).

Evaluate benefits and risks of using antibiotics to manage bacterial infection; include historical context of penicillin use and the rise of bacterial resistance and implications for treatment and public health (HSW2, HSW5, HSW9, HSW12).

Explain biodiversity at different levels: habitat biodiversity (e.g. sand dunes, woodland, meadows, streams), species biodiversity (species richness and species evenness), and genetic biodiversity (different breeds within a species).
Explain how and why sampling is used to measure biodiversity of a habitat; justify representativeness and reliability; distinguish random vs non-random approaches.

Carry out practical investigations collecting random and non-random samples in the field; include random sampling and non-random (opportunistic, stratified, systematic) and techniques: quadrats, sweep nets, pitfall traps, pooters; interpret sampling data and limitations (M0.2, M1.3, M1.4, M1.5, M1.6, M1.7, M1.9, M1.10, M3.2; PAG3; HSW4, HSW5, HSW6).
Measure and interpret species richness and species evenness in a habitat; perform calculations and compare habitats (M1.1, M1.5, M2.3, M2.4).

Use and interpret Simpson’s Index of Diversity (D) to calculate biodiversity; formula provided in assessment; interpret high vs low D values; apply to sampling datasets (M1.1, M1.5, M2.3, M2.4; HSW5).

Assess genetic biodiversity including calculations of genetic diversity in isolated populations, e.g. percentage of gene variants (alleles) and proportion of polymorphic gene loci = number of polymorphic gene loci / total number of loci; apply to contexts such as zoos, rare breeds, pedigree animals (M1.1, M1.5, M2.3, M2.4; HSW5).

Explain factors affecting biodiversity including human population growth, agriculture (monoculture) and climate change; interpret data and trends where provided (M1.3, M1.7, M3.1; HSW5, HSW10, HSW12).

Explain ecological, economic and aesthetic reasons for maintaining biodiversity: ecological (protecting keystone species, interdependence, maintaining genetic resource), economic (reducing soil depletion/continuous monoculture), aesthetic (protecting landscapes) (HSW12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: In situ and ex situ conservation
Sub_topics.description: Describe in situ and ex situ methods of maintaining biodiversity: in situ (marine conservation zones, wildlife reserves) and ex situ (seed banks, botanic gardens, zoos); evaluate strengths/limitations (HSW7, HSW9, HSW10, HSW12).

Describe international and local conservation agreements protecting species/habitats, including Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), Rio Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), and Countryside Stewardship Scheme (CSS); evaluate how policy influences outcomes (HSW11, HSW12).
Describe biological classification hierarchy: kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species; include domain as a higher level (HSW1, HSW5, HSW6, HSW7).
Explain binomial system of naming species and advantages (standardisation, avoiding ambiguity across languages/regions).
Describe features used to classify organisms into five kingdoms: Prokaryotae, Protoctista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia; relate observable characteristics to classification decisions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for new classification systems (three domains)
Sub_topics.description: Explain evidence leading to new classification systems (three domains of life) clarifying relationships; include shift from observable features to molecular/genetic evidence; compare kingdom vs domain classification systems; describe three domains and their distinguishing features (HSW1, HSW5, HSW6, HSW7, HSW11, HSW12).
Explain relationship between classification and phylogeny (evolutionary relationships); no requirement to know cladistics (HSW5, HSW7).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for evolution by natural selection
Sub_topics.description: Explain evidence for theory of evolution by natural selection; include contributions of Darwin and Wallace; include fossil evidence, DNA evidence (genomic DNA at AS level) and molecular evidence; evaluate strength/limitations of evidence types (HSW1, HSW2, HSW5, HSW6, HSW7).

Describe intraspecific vs interspecific variation; continuous vs discontinuous variation using examples from plants, animals and microorganisms; explain genetic and environmental causes; interpret data distributions (M1.2, M1.3, M1.6, M1.7, M1.9, M1.10; HSW4).
Explain anatomical, physiological and behavioural adaptations; explain why organisms from different taxonomic groups may show similar anatomical features (convergent evolution) (HSW5).

Explain mechanism of natural selection changing population characteristics over time: genetic variation + selection pressure + differential reproductive success → increased proportion with advantageous characteristics; apply to scenarios; may include proportional reasoning (M0.3; HSW8).

Explain implications of evolution in some species for human populations, including evolution of pesticide resistance in insects and drug resistance in microorganisms; relate to selection pressures and management strategies (HSW8, HSW9, HSW12).
Explain need for communication systems in multicellular organisms: respond to internal/external environment changes and coordinate activities of different organs; include plant and animal examples.
Explain communication between cells by cell signalling, including signalling between adjacent cells and between distant cells; relate to receptors, ligands and response pathways.
Explain principles of homeostasis including roles of receptors and effectors; distinguish negative vs positive feedback; apply to control systems (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Temperature control in ectotherms and endotherms
Sub_topics.description: Describe physiological and behavioural responses in temperature control: endotherms (peripheral temperature receptors, hypothalamus role, effectors in skin and muscles, behavioural responses) and ectotherms (behavioural responses); relate to maintaining core temperature (PAG11, HSW2).

Topics.Topic_name: Excretion as an example of homeostatic control

Sub_topics.description: Define excretion and explain importance in maintaining metabolism and homeostasis; include removal of metabolic wastes such as carbon dioxide and nitrogenous waste.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Liver structure and functions (incl. urea formation)
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure and functions of mammalian liver (gross structure and histology); roles: glycogen storage, detoxification, formation of urea from ammonia reacting with CO2 as part of ornithine cycle (no detailed ornithine cycle steps required).
Examine and draw stained sections showing histology of liver tissue; identify key features and relate to function (PAG1, HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kidney and nephron structure; urine production processes
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure, mechanisms of action and functions of mammalian kidney; include gross structure and histology, detailed nephron structure and associated blood vessels; explain ultrafiltration, selective reabsorption and urine production; apply calculations to filtration and flow where needed (M0.1, M0.3, M1.1, M1.3, M2.1, M3.1).
Dissect, examine and draw external and internal structure of kidney; identify cortex/medulla/pelvis and associated structures (PAG2, HSW4).
Examine and draw stained sections showing histology of nephrons; identify key components and relate to function (PAG1, HSW4, HSW6, HSW8).
Explain control of water potential of blood: osmoreceptors in hypothalamus, posterior pituitary gland, ADH release, and effect on collecting duct walls (e.g. aquaporins) (HSW8).

Explain effects of kidney failure including impacts on glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and electrolyte balance; outline treatments: renal dialysis (haemodialysis only) and transplants; evaluate risks/benefits (HSW7, HSW9, HSW12).

Explain how excretory products are used in medical diagnosis; include urine sample tests, monoclonal antibodies in pregnancy testing, and testing for anabolic steroids and drugs (PAG9, HSW7, HSW9, HSW11, HSW12).
Explain roles of mammalian sensory receptors in converting stimuli into nerve impulses; include specificity and an example such as Pacinian corpuscle; use term transducer correctly.
Describe structure and functions of sensory, relay and motor neurones; compare myelinated vs non-myelinated neurones and relate to conduction speed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resting potential and action potential (myelinated neurone)
Sub_topics.description: Explain generation and transmission of nerve impulses: how resting potential is established and maintained; how action potential is generated including positive feedback; how action potentials propagate in myelinated neurones (saltatory conduction); significance of frequency of impulse transmission; interpret simple data/graphs (M1.3, M3.1).

Describe structure and roles of synapses in neurotransmission; include structure of a cholinergic synapse, action of neurotransmitters, importance of synapses in summation, and inhibitory vs excitatory synapses.
Explain endocrine communication by hormones: secretion into blood, transport in blood, and detection by target cells/tissues via specific receptors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Adrenal glands: cortex and medulla hormones
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure and functions of adrenal glands; include hormones secreted by adrenal cortex and medulla and their functions; relate to stress responses.
Describe histology of pancreas focusing on endocrine tissues (islets) and relation to hormone secretion.
Examine and draw stained sections of pancreas showing endocrine tissues; identify features relevant to insulin/glucagon secretion (PAG1, HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Blood glucose regulation (insulin, glucagon; beta-cell channels)
Sub_topics.description: Explain regulation of blood glucose concentration using insulin and glucagon as negative feedback and role of liver; include control of insulin secretion with reference to potassium channels and calcium channels in pancreatic beta cells (HSW12).
Explain differences between Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes mellitus: causes and treatments for each; relate to insulin production vs insulin resistance (HSW12).
Outline potential treatments for diabetes mellitus including insulin produced by genetically modified bacteria and potential use of stem cells; evaluate implications (HSW12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Types of plant responses (tropisms; stress; herbivory)
Sub_topics.description: Describe types of plant responses including responses to abiotic stress and herbivory; herbivory responses include chemical defences (alkaloids and pheromones only) and folding in response to touch; describe range of tropisms in plants; interpret simple response data (M1.3, M1.6).
Carry out/interpret practical investigations into phototropism and geotropism; control variables and measure growth/curvature responses (PAG11, HSW4).
Explain roles of plant hormones in leaf loss (abscission) in deciduous plants, seed germination, and stomatal closure; link to environmental control.

Explain experimental evidence for role of auxins in control of apical dominance; relate auxin concentration to lateral bud growth; apply understanding to unfamiliar experimental setups; no need to recall specific experiments (HSW5).

Explain experimental evidence for role of gibberellin in control of stem elongation and seed germination; relate gibberellin concentration to elongation; apply to unfamiliar experiments; no need to recall specific experiments (HSW5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Investigate plant hormones on growth (serial dilutions)
Sub_topics.description: Carry out/interpret practical investigations into effects of plant hormones on growth; include serial dilutions, appropriate sampling and statistical/graph handling as needed (M0.2, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.4, M1.6, M1.9, M1.10, M3.1, M3.2; PAG11; HSW4).
Explain commercial use of plant hormones: controlling ripening, rooting powders, hormonal weed killers; evaluate benefits and risks (HSW12).
Describe organisation of mammalian nervous system: structural (central nervous system vs peripheral nervous system) and functional (somatic vs autonomic nervous systems).
Describe gross structure of human brain and functions of cerebrum, cerebellum, medulla oblongata, hypothalamus and pituitary gland.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reflex actions (knee jerk) and survival value
Sub_topics.description: Explain reflex actions using knee jerk reflex; include pathway concept and survival value; may include measurement of reaction/response where relevant (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.6; PAG11; HSW4).

Explain coordination of responses by nervous and endocrine systems: fight-or-flight response; outline hormone cell signalling with adrenaline as first messenger, activation of adenylyl cyclase, and cyclic AMP (cAMP) as second messenger.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hormonal and nervous effects on heart rate (practical)
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of hormones and nervous mechanisms on heart rate; carry out/interpret monitoring of physiological functions (pulse rate before/during/after exercise or sensors for electrical heart activity); analyse data (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.6, M1.10, M3.1; PAG10, PAG11; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Muscle types and sliding filament model
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure of mammalian muscle and mechanism of muscular contraction: differences between skeletal, involuntary and cardiac muscle; neuromuscular junctions; sliding filament model; role of ATP; how ATP supply maintained by creatine phosphate.
Examine stained sections or photomicrographs of skeletal muscle; identify features (e.g. fibres, striations) and relate to contraction mechanism (PAG1, PAG10, PAG11; HSW4).

Explain interrelationship between photosynthesis and respiration, including relationship between raw materials and products; apply to carbon flow and energy transfer contexts (M0.1, M0.3, M0.4, M3.4).
Describe chloroplast structure and identify sites of two main stages of photosynthesis; include outer membrane, lamellae, grana, thylakoid, stroma and DNA.
Explain importance of photosynthetic pigments in photosynthesis; include light harvesting systems and photosystems; relate absorption spectra to efficiency.

Carry out/interpret practical investigations using thin layer chromatography (TLC) to separate photosynthetic pigments; calculate/interpret distances/Rf where relevant and handle data (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.3, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4; PAG6; HSW4).

Explain light-dependent stage: harvesting light energy to produce ATP and reduced NADP; include electron carriers, cyclic and non-cyclic photophosphorylation; role of water (photolysis) and oxygen production (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Carbon fixation and Calvin cycle outputs
Sub_topics.description: Explain fixation of CO2 and light-independent stage (Calvin cycle) producing triose phosphate (TP); include roles of RuBP, RuBisCO and GP; no other biochemical detail required; relate to regeneration steps conceptually (HSW8).
Explain uses of TP as starting material for synthesis of carbohydrates, lipids and amino acids; explain recycling of TP to regenerate RuBP; relate allocation to growth/storage.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Limiting factors and water stress effects
Sub_topics.description: Explain factors affecting photosynthesis: limiting factors (CO2 concentration, light intensity, temperature) and implications of water stress (stomatal closure); explain effects on photosynthesis rate and levels of GP, RuBP and TP when changing CO2, light or temperature.

Carry out/interpret practical investigations into factors affecting rate of photosynthesis; analyse data with rates/graphs/tangents and uncertainties (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M1.1, M1.3, M1.11, M3.1, M3.2, M3.4, M3.5, M3.6, M4.1; PAG4, PAG10, PAG11; HSW3, HSW4, HSW5, HSW12).
Explain need for cellular respiration in plants, animals and microorganisms; include examples such as active transport and named metabolic reactions in outline.
Describe mitochondrion structure: inner and outer mitochondrial membranes, cristae, matrix and mitochondrial DNA; relate to sites of respiration stages.

Explain glycolysis and its site; include phosphorylation of glucose to hexose bisphosphate, splitting to two TP molecules and oxidation to pyruvate; production of small yield of ATP and reduced NAD (HSW8).
Explain link reaction and its site: pyruvate decarboxylation to form acetyl CoA and reduction of NAD to reduced NAD.

Explain Krebs cycle and its site: citrate formation from acetyl group + oxaloacetate; reconversion to oxaloacetate (no intermediate names required); importance of decarboxylation, dehydrogenation, reduction of NAD and FAD, and substrate-level phosphorylation (HSW8).
Explain importance of coenzymes NAD, FAD and coenzyme A in cellular respiration; relate to hydrogen/electron transfer and acetyl group transfer.
Explain oxidative phosphorylation and its site; include roles of electron carriers, oxygen as final electron acceptor, and mitochondrial cristae in providing surface area.
Explain chemiosmotic theory: electron transport chain, proton gradients, ATP synthase in oxidative phosphorylation and photophosphorylation; relate gradient to ATP production.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anaerobic respiration in mammals and yeast
Sub_topics.description: Describe anaerobic respiration in eukaryotes (mammals and yeast); explain benefits of anaerobic respiration and why it yields much less ATP than aerobic respiration.

Carry out/interpret practical investigations into respiration rates in yeast under aerobic and anaerobic conditions; analyse data with rates/graphs (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.3, M2.4, M3.1, M3.2; PAG4, PAG10, PAG11; HSW3, HSW4).
Explain differences in relative energy values of carbohydrates, lipids and proteins as respiratory substrates; relate to oxidation state and hydrogen content.
Calculate and interpret respiratory quotient RQ = CO2 produced / O2 consumed; use to infer substrate being respired; apply to datasets (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.3, M2.3).

Carry out/interpret practical investigations into effects of factors (temperature, substrate concentration, different respiratory substrates) on respiration rate; include use of respirometers; analyse uncertainty and graph slopes/tangents (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.2, M1.3, M1.6, M1.10, M2.4, M3.2, M3.3, M3.5, M3.6; PAG4, PAG10, PAG11; HSW3, HSW4).
Describe types of gene mutation: substitution, insertion, deletion of one or more nucleotides; explain possible effects on protein production and function (beneficial, neutral, harmful).

Explain regulatory mechanisms controlling gene expression at: transcriptional level (lac operon; general role of transcription factors in eukaryotes—no need to recall specific factors), post-transcriptional level (editing of primary mRNA; removal of introns to form mature mRNA), and post-translational level (activation of proteins by cyclic AMP) (HSW2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Homeobox and Hox genes in body plans
Sub_topics.description: Explain genetic control of development of body plans: homeobox gene sequences are similar/highly conserved in plants, animals and fungi and regulate gene expression; describe role of Hox genes (subset of homeobox genes) controlling body plan development (HSW7).
Explain importance of mitosis and apoptosis in controlling development of body form; recognise genes regulating cell cycle and apoptosis respond to internal/external cell stimuli.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Environmental and genetic contributions to phenotype
Sub_topics.description: Explain contribution of environmental and genetic factors to phenotypic variation; include examples such as diet in animals and etiolation in plants.
Explain how sexual reproduction leads to genetic variation within a species: meiosis and random fusion of gametes at fertilisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic diagrams (monogenic, dihybrid, multiple alleles, sex linkage, codominance)
Sub_topics.description: Construct and interpret genetic diagrams to show inheritance patterns: monogenic inheritance, dihybrid inheritance, multiple alleles, sex linkage and codominance; use standard genetic notation and predict offspring genotypes/phenotypes.

Use phenotypic ratios to identify linkage (autosomal and sex linkage) and epistasis; explain linkage and epistasis and how they alter expected Mendelian ratios; apply proportional reasoning (M0.3, M1.4; HSW2, HSW8).

Use chi-squared (χ²) test to determine significance of difference between observed and expected results; formula provided; choose degrees of freedom and interpret outcome in biological context (M0.3, M1.4, M1.9, M2.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic basis of continuous vs discontinuous variation
Sub_topics.description: Explain genetic basis of continuous and discontinuous variation with reference to number of genes influencing each type; relate polygenic inheritance to continuous distributions.
Explain factors affecting evolution of a species: stabilising selection, directional selection, genetic drift, genetic bottleneck, founder effect; apply to population change scenarios.

Use Hardy–Weinberg principle to calculate allele frequencies in populations; equations provided (p^2 + 2pq + q^2 = 1 and p + q = 1); apply to genotype frequency data and interpret assumptions/limitations (M0.2, M2.1, M2.2, M2.3).
Explain role of isolating mechanisms in evolution of new species: geographical (allopatric speciation) and reproductive (sympatric speciation).
Explain principles of artificial selection (selective breeding) and its uses in plants and animals; recognise importance of maintaining genetic material resources including wild types.
Evaluate ethical considerations of artificial selection, including extreme selective breeding examples (e.g. dog breeds) and welfare/genetic diversity impacts (HSW2, HSW8, HSW10, HSW12).
Explain principles of DNA sequencing and new techniques; understand progression from Sanger sequencing to high throughput sequencing; no detailed knowledge of high throughput methods required (HSW7).
Explain how gene sequencing enables genome-wide comparisons between individuals and species; link to bioinformatics/computational biology applications (HSW7, HSW9).
Explain how gene sequencing allows prediction of amino acid sequences in polypeptides; relate codons to amino acids and use of databases/tools (PAG10).
Explain how gene sequencing supports development of synthetic biology; relate to designing/constructing new biological parts/systems and bioinformatics roles (HSW7, HSW9).
Explain principles of DNA profiling and its uses including forensics and analysis of disease risk; interpret profile comparisons (HSW9).
Explain principles of polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and its application in DNA analysis; include cycles of denaturation, annealing, extension and role of primers/DNA polymerase at conceptual level.
Explain principles and uses of electrophoresis to separate nucleic acid fragments or proteins; interpret banding patterns; opportunity for practical electrophoresis (PAG6, HSW4).
Explain principles of genetic engineering: isolating genes from one organism and placing them into another using suitable vectors; relate to recombinant DNA and expression.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic engineering techniques (restriction enzymes, plasmids, ligase, electroporation)
Sub_topics.description: Describe techniques used in genetic engineering: restriction enzymes, plasmids, DNA ligase to form recombinant DNA, and electroporation to introduce vectors; apply steps to novel examples (HSW2).

Discuss ethical issues (positive and negative) of genetic manipulation of animals (including humans), plants and microorganisms; include examples: insect resistance in GM soya, GM pathogens for research, pharming (GM animals producing pharmaceuticals), patenting and technology transfer (e.g. GM seed availability to poor farmers) (HSW10).
Explain principles and potential of gene therapy in medicine; distinguish somatic cell gene therapy vs germ line gene therapy; evaluate benefits/risks and ethical issues (HSW9, HSW12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Natural cloning in plants and horticulture
Sub_topics.description: Describe natural clones in plants and production of natural clones for horticulture; include vegetative propagation methods and why clones are useful.
Explain and carry out taking plant cuttings as simple cloning technique; include dissection of plant material and conditions to promote rooting (PAG2, HSW4).
Explain production of artificial clones of plants by micropropagation and tissue culture; include aseptic conditions, use of meristems, and growth regulators conceptually.
Evaluate arguments for and against artificial cloning in plants; include horticulture/agriculture uses, disease risk, reduced genetic diversity, cost, conservation implications (HSW9, HSW12).
Describe natural clones in animal species, including twins formed by embryo splitting; relate to genetic identity and developmental environment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Artificial cloning in animals (embryo twinning, SCNT)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how artificial clones in animals can be produced by artificial embryo twinning and by enucleation and somatic cell nuclear transfer (SCNT); outline steps and roles of nucleus/cytoplasm.
Evaluate arguments for and against artificial cloning in animals; include uses in agriculture and medicine and issues such as longevity of cloned animals (HSW9, HSW10, HSW12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Microorganisms in biotechnology: reasons for use
Sub_topics.description: Explain use of microorganisms in biotechnological processes and reasons: economic considerations, short life cycle, and growth requirements; relate to scaling production.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Microbial food production: pros and cons
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate advantages and disadvantages of using microorganisms to make food for human consumption; include bacterial and fungal sources; consider nutrition, efficiency, acceptance, safety (HSW9, HSW12).

Describe and apply effective culturing of microorganisms using aseptic techniques; include sterile equipment, inoculation, incubation conditions and safe disposal; include serial dilutions and agar/broth where relevant (PAG7, HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Batch vs continuous fermentation and yield
Sub_topics.description: Explain importance of manipulating growing conditions in batch and continuous fermentation to maximise yield; include factors such as nutrients, oxygen, pH, temperature, removal of waste/products.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Standard growth curve in closed culture
Sub_topics.description: Describe standard growth curve of a microorganism in closed culture (lag, log/exponential, stationary, decline); relate phase changes to nutrient/waste factors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Investigate microbial growth factors; exponential model
Sub_topics.description: Carry out/interpret practical investigations into factors affecting growth of microorganisms; use formula N = N0 × 2^n for number of organisms; apply logs/exponentials and data handling (M0.1, M0.3, M0.5, M1.1, M1.3, M2.5, M3.1, M3.2, M3.4, M3.5, M3.6; PAG7; HSW4).

Explain uses of immobilised enzymes in biotechnology and different methods of immobilisation; evaluate benefits/limitations (e.g. reuse, stability, product purity, cost); apply understanding to contexts such as glucose isomerase, penicillin acylase, lactase, aminoacylase, glucoamylase; examples need not be recalled but must be applied in context (M0.2, M0.3, M1.2, M1.3, M1.4, M1.6, M1.10, M3.2, M4.1; PAG4; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ecosystems as dynamic; biotic and abiotic factors
Sub_topics.description: Explain that ecosystems range in size, are dynamic, and influenced by biotic and abiotic factors; include examples of different-sized ecosystems (rock pool, playing field, large tree) and named biotic/abiotic factors.

Explain biomass transfers through ecosystems: how transfers between trophic levels are measured; efficiency of biomass transfer with formula efficiency = (biomass transferred / biomass intake) × 100; explain how human activities can manipulate biomass transfer; apply calculations and interpret pyramids/data (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M0.4, M1.1, M1.3, M1.6; HSW12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Recycling: decomposers; nitrogen and carbon cycles
Sub_topics.description: Explain recycling within ecosystems: role of decomposers; roles of microorganisms in nitrogen recycling including Nitrosomonas, Nitrobacter, Azotobacter and Rhizobium; importance of carbon cycle including roles of organisms (decomposition, respiration, photosynthesis) and physical/chemical effects; link to ecosystem stability (HSW2, HSW12).
Describe primary succession from pioneer species to climax community and explain deflected succession; relate changes to abiotic conditions and species interactions (HSW12).
Explain how distribution and abundance of organisms in an ecosystem can be measured; choose appropriate sampling/recording approaches and justify (M1.3, M1.4, M1.5, M1.7, M1.9, M1.10, M3.1, M3.2).

Use sampling and recording methods to determine distribution and abundance in ecosystems; include quadrats, transects and appropriate data presentation/analysis; evaluate sampling limitations (PAG3, HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Population size factors and carrying capacity
Sub_topics.description: Explain factors determining size of a population; include significance of limiting factors and carrying capacity; analyse population growth data and apply appropriate maths (M0.1, M0.2, M0.3, M0.4, M0.5, M1.3, M2.5, M3.1, M3.2; HSW1, HSW2).

Explain interactions between populations: predator–prey relationships and effects on predator and prey population sizes; interspecific and intraspecific competition; interpret population cycle graphs.
Explain reasons for and differences between conservation and preservation; include economic, social and ethical reasons for conserving biological resources (HSW7, HSW9, HSW10, HSW12).
Explain how management of an ecosystem can provide resources sustainably; limited to management for timber production and fishing; evaluate strategies and impacts (HSW12).

Explain management of environmental resources to balance conservation/preservation with human needs; describe effects of human activities on animal and plant populations and how these are controlled; evaluate ecological consequences (HSW7, HSW12).
